name: HD 206255
scenarioDescription:
The HD 206255 Exoplanetary System

HD 206255 is a star with 1.42 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.206 times its radius. It is located 245.92 light years away from the solar system.

HD 206255 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

HD 206255 b

HD 206255 b was discovered by the Las Campanas Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2019-04. Its semi-major axis is 0.46 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 96.05 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 206255.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.23, which means that when HD 206255 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.35 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.57. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 206255 b is 34.20 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 206255 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 206255, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Las Campanas Observatory.
